awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Intensive Mothering and Maternal Physical Health
awd_abstract_narration:
This project explores the health impacts of intensive mothering.  Women spend far more time with their children today than in the past several decades. The high cost to parenting may create tensions between investment in children and investment in self.  Three principal research questions are addressed: 1) How intensive mothering beliefs and behaviors affect maternal physical health; 2) How the effects in 1) vary by social class and employment status; and 3) How the relationship between intensive mothering and child health is affected by maternal physical health.  Findings will have implications for both formal health policies and more informal advocacy for maternal self-care.

This study will conduct a longitudinal analysis using panel data from the Avon Longitudinal Survey of Parents and Children (ALSPAC).  This will allow disentangling of the relationships between modern motherhood, maternal health, and child health.  The project will address past contradictory evidence on motherhood, social class, and employment status.  In addition, it will address recent debates in the literature surrounding the operationalization of intensive mothering.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Co-PI completed this research for her dissertation titled "Intensive Mothering and Maternal Physical Health." Intensive mothering behaviors involve high amounts of time, energy, and money devoted to childrearing. Intensive mothering ideologies correspondingly assert this high investment is necessary for child success, development, and well-being. This dissertation considers a) how mothers adhere to, reject, and combine various facets of intensive mothering behaviors and attitudes, and b) how intensive mothering is related to maternal body mass index (a measure of obesity) over time.

Project Results:

First, this project investigated patterns in mothers' intensive mothering across a set of behaviors and attitudes, including: time spent engaged with children, breastfeeding duration, monetary assets set away for children, emotional strain caused by parenting, and gender essentialist views (the degree to which they believe mothers are more essential for child development than fathers). Four general patterns were identified. The most common group/pattern observed in the data were labeled "Relaxed Mothers," as these mothers were not very intensive on either mothering behaviors or attitudes. The second group, "High Investors," were high on behaviors (i.e., large amounts of time spent with kids, long breastfeeding duration, assets set away for children), but didn?t feel much emotional strain or express essentialist views. The third group, "Essentialist Mothers," were not intensive on behaviors and had low emotional strain, but expressed essentialist views. The final group, "Strained Mothers," were low on behaviors, were not essentialist, but reported high emotional strain. Compared to High Investors and Strained Mothers, Relaxed and Essentialist Mothers were overall less socially advantaged, averaging a lower level of education, age, and household income; and a higher likelihood of being Black and/or a single mother. In contrast, compared to Relaxed and Essentialist Mothers, High Investors and Strained Mothers were more socially advantaged, averaging a higher level of education, age, and household income, as well as a lower likelihood of being Black and/or a single mother.

Second, this project investigated how intensive mothering is related to changes in mothers' body mass index (BMI) over a 22-year period. Compared to non-intensive mothers, those identified as intensive mothers had a lower starting BMI, but on average gained more weight (leading to an increase in their BMI) over time. This being said, differences between non-intensive mothers and intensive mothers were not statistically significant. Next steps include: excluding all observations where the mother's weight was reported by the father (and therefore not reported by herself); examining other facets of intensive mothering (in isolation, as well as in combination) and their relationships with maternal weight; and extending the analyses to look at the relationship between motherhood and overall maternal health.

Intellectual Merit:

This project has several important implications for future studies and current sociological theory. The results suggest there is more variation in intensive mothering than has been highlighted in past work. Past theory predicts that mothers who are intensive in one area of their parenting will be more likely to be intensive in all other areas as well. In contrast to prior literature, the results imply this is not the case, as mothers in the sample were frequently intensive in one area but non-intensive in others. Further, while intensive mothering is often described as the most common form of mothering in western countries, the most common pattern of mothering in the data was fairly non-intensive. This has an important implication for future studies: scholars should seek to more fully understand non-intensive mothers, as they are a non-trivial part of the population.

Based on prior research, intensive mothering was expected to have a negative, significant association with maternal physical health (meaning, all other things equal, intensive mothers would on average have worse health outcomes than non-intensive mothers). Yet a significant relationship between intensive mothering and maternal obesity was not found in the data. This does not rule out the possibility of negative effects for maternal physical health, but it does suggest that intensive mothering may not have a straightforward, consistent relationship with well-being.

The Co-PI disseminated these findings at the Population Research Institute's Brown Bag Lecture Series and the annual meeting of the Population Association of America. Results from the first half of the project were compiled in a manuscript and submitted to an academic journal. Results from the second half of the project are currently being compiled into a manuscript.

Broader Impacts:

The relationship between intensive mothering and maternal physical health is an important clarification for public policy, governmental agencies, and non-profit organizations, particularly because many countries now actively encourage intensive mothering as a means of improving child development. This addresses the NSF's goal of improved well-being of individuals in society.
